item.title: beego#1
item.description:
beego write_error

在tornado中，controller有一个write\_error的方法，可以重置http code，并且写http body。beego默认提供的Abort只能自定义输出模板，并且返回值不是所需要的code。

下面代码实现了类似功能 go

type BaseController struct { beego.Controller }

func (self *BaseController) WriteError(errCode int, errMsg string) { self.Ctx.Abort(errCode, errMsg) beego.Error(errMsg) }

item.title: go-lang-test
item.description:
golang-snippet iconv

To use libiconv, we could use the mahonia package from https://code.google.com/p/mahonia.

install

go get -u code.google.com/p/mahonia

example

package main

import (
    "bufio"
    "fmt"
    "io"
    "log"
    "mahonia"
    "os"
)

var filename = "/Users/fatman/workspace/scripts/cup/acl/test_data/cvsmain2/CVSROOT/modules"

func checkError(err interface{}) {
    if err != nil {
        log.Fatal(err)
    }
}

func main() {
    f, err := os.Open(filename)
    checkError(err)
    defer f.Close()
    decoder := mahonia.NewDecoder("gb18030")
    r := bufio.NewReader(decoder.NewReader(f))
    //p := make([]byte, 1<<16)
    //n, err1 := r.Read(p)
    //checkError(err1)
    //fmt.Println(n)
    //fmt.Println(string(p))
    for {
        s, err := r.ReadString('\n')
        if err != nil {
            if err == io.EOF {
                break
            } else {
                log.Fatal(err)
            }
        }
        fmt.Print(s)
    }
}

Quite easy, isn’t it?

item.title: launchctl使用
item.description:
launchctl是Mac OS X中用来控制守护进程的一个工具。配合plist，可以达到启动、停止某服务的作用。

假设有一个com.example.foobar.plist文件，启动

launchctl load com.example.foobar.plist
launchctl unload com.example.foobar.plist

比较遗憾的是没有reload功能。更加简单的理解就是linux下面的/etc/init.d/下面的内容。

item.title: yum tips
item.description:
As we all know, Redhat Linux and its variants (CentOS, Fedora) use yum as their default package manager. However, we cannot list the content of one rpm package only with the yum command.

One approach to solve the problem is download the rpm file and use

rpm -qlp rpm-file-name

The disadvantage and inconveniece is obvious.

The best way is

yum install yum-utils
repoquery -lq package-name

item.title: Data mining with R notes: 1
item.description:
Introduction

I am now reading Data Mining With R, and I am taking notes. The original plot-system of the book is lattice. However, I am going to replace it with ggplot2.

Predicting Algae Blooms

It is a classic prediction problem. 200 training data are given.

Loading Data

library(ggplot2)
library(DMwR)
head(algae)

the results are shown below

season  size  speed mxPH mnO2     Cl    NO3     NH4    oPO4     PO4 Chla   a1   a2   a3  a4   a5   a6  a7
1 winter small medium 8.00  9.8 60.800  6.238 578.000 105.000 170.000 50.0  0.0  0.0  0.0 0.0 34.2  8.3 0.0
2 spring small medium 8.35  8.0 57.750  1.288 370.000 428.750 558.750  1.3  1.4  7.6  4.8 1.9  6.7  0.0 2.1
3 autumn small medium 8.10 11.4 40.020  5.330 346.667 125.667 187.057 15.6  3.3 53.6  1.9 0.0  0.0  0.0 9.7
4 spring small medium 8.07  4.8 77.364  2.302  98.182  61.182 138.700  1.4  3.1 41.0 18.9 0.0  1.4  0.0 1.4
5 autumn small medium 8.06  9.0 55.350 10.416 233.700  58.222  97.580 10.5  9.2  2.9  7.5 0.0  7.5  4.1 1.0
6 winter small   high 8.25 13.1 65.750  9.248 430.000  18.250  56.667 28.4 15.1 14.6  1.4 0.0 22.5 12.6 2.9

Visualization

ggplot2 is a handful plotting tool. The only disadvantage is that it support 2D plotting only.

Show the boxplot of size and a1: r qplot(size, a1, geom='boxplot')

Show the histogram of mxPH: r qplot(mxPH, data=algae, geom='histogram', binwidth=0.4)

Handle unknown values

Usually, there 4 ways to handle the unknowns.

  1. Remove the cases withs unkowns.
  2. Fill in the unknown values by exploring the correlations between variables.
  3. Fill in the unknown values by exploring the similarity between cases.
  4. Use tools that are able to handle these values.

remove unknown values

the complete.cases() function will tell whether a case is complete or not. r complete.cases(algae) #a boolean vector algae.complete = algae[complete.cases(algae),] #because algae is a data frame nrow(algae.complete) #184

Or, we can simply omit the NAs with one line: r algae.complete = na.omit(algae)

Sometimes, it is useful to find out how many NAs there are in one row. R supports anonymous function, so we can do r apply(algae, 1, function(x) sum(is.na(x)))

fill in the unknowns with the most frequent values

Mean, Median, and Mode are 3 ways to fill in the blanks. We should decide which one to use by the shape of its distribution. For example. the normal distribution is symetric and the obseravtions are clustered around the mean, thus, the Mean statistic is a good choice. For skewed distribution, or there are some obvious outliers in the sample, the mean may be incorrect. So the median may be a better choice.

Caculate the mean of the mxPH, removing the unknowns. r mxPH.mean = mean(algae$mxPH, na.rm = TRUE)

Fill the blanks: r algae[is.na(algae$mxPH), "mxPH"] = mean(algae$mxPH, na.rm = TRUE) algae[is.na(algae$Chla), "Chla"] = median(algae$Chla, na.rm = TRUE)

fill in the unknowns by exploring correlations

To obtain the variables correlation we can issue the command: r cor(algae[, 4:18], use = "complete.obs")

This gives us a numerical matrix which may be difficult to get the correlation whose absolute value is close to 1. So r symnum(cor(algae[,4:18], use = "complete.obs"))

In our data, the correlations are in most cases irrelevant. However, there are two exceptions: between variables NH4 and NO3, and between PO4 and oPO4. These two latter variables are strongly correlated (above 0.9). The correlation between NH4 and NO3 is less evident (0.72) and thus it is risky to take advantage of it to fill in the unknowns.

We could do a linear regression.

lm(PO4 ~ oPO4, data=algae)

We get the coefficients, a=1.293, b=42.897, so fill in the blank: r algae[28, "PO4"] = 42.897 + 1.293 * algae[28, "oPO4"]

filling in the unknown values by exploring similarities between cases

Instead of exploring the correlation between the columns (variables) of a dataset, we can try to use the similarities between the rows (observations) to fill in the unknown values.

First, we define a metric, the Euclidean norm is mostly used. Then, we find the k most nearest point to the point which has NA. The weight is caculated by the Gaussion kernel function w(d) = e^{-d}. For nominal variables, the distance is 1 if they are not equal, otherwise it is set to 0. These distances are caculated after normalizing the numeric values.

knnImputation = function (data, k = 10, scale = T, meth = "weighAvg", distData = NULL) 
{
    n <- nrow(data)
    if (!is.null(distData)) {
        distInit <- n + 1
        data <- rbind(data, distData)
    }
    else distInit <- 1
    N <- nrow(data)
    ncol <- ncol(data)
    nomAttrs <- rep(F, ncol)
    for (i in seq(ncol)) nomAttrs[i] <- is.factor(data[, i])
    nomAttrs <- which(nomAttrs)
    hasNom <- length(nomAttrs)
    contAttrs <- setdiff(seq(ncol), nomAttrs)
    dm <- data
    if (scale) 
        dm[, contAttrs] <- scale(dm[, contAttrs])
    if (hasNom) 
        for (i in nomAttrs) dm[, i] <- as.integer(dm[, i])
    dm <- as.matrix(dm)
    nas <- which(!complete.cases(dm))
    if (!is.null(distData)) 
        tgt.nas <- nas[nas <= n]
    else tgt.nas <- nas
    if (length(tgt.nas) == 0) 
        warning("No case has missing values. Stopping as there is nothing to do.")
    xcomplete <- dm[setdiff(distInit:N, nas), ]
    if (nrow(xcomplete) < k) 
        stop("Not sufficient complete cases for computing neighbors.")
    for (i in tgt.nas) {
        tgtAs <- which(is.na(dm[i, ]))
        dist <- scale(xcomplete, dm[i, ], FALSE)
        xnom <- setdiff(nomAttrs, tgtAs)
        if (length(xnom)) 
            dist[, xnom] <- ifelse(dist[, xnom] > 0, 1, dist[, 
                xnom])
        dist <- dist[, -tgtAs]
        dist <- sqrt(drop(dist^2 %*% rep(1, ncol(dist))))
        ks <- order(dist)[seq(k)]
        for (j in tgtAs) if (meth == "median") 
            data[i, j] <- centralValue(data[setdiff(distInit:N, 
                nas), j][ks])
        else data[i, j] <- centralValue(data[setdiff(distInit:N, 
            nas), j][ks], exp(-dist[ks]))
    }
    data[1:n, ]
}

clean.algae = knnImputation(algae, k=10)

linear model

lm.a1 = lm(a1 ~ ., data = clean.algae[, 1:12])
summary(lm.a1)
plot(lm.a1)
anova(lm.a1)
final.lm.a1 = step(lm.a1)

For nominal variables, R will create auxiliaray variables. For example, the season variable, R will create seasonspring, seasonsummer and seasonwinter, if all these variables are 0, then the value of season is autumn.

With the result, we could see the R-square is only 0.32, which indicates that the linear model does not fit the data well.

regression tree

Use a regression tree model. r library(rpart) rt.a1 = rpart(a1 ~ ., data=algae[,1:12]) plot(rt.a1) text(rt.a1) summary(rt.a1)

item.title: R plot 1
item.description:
绘图功能是R的杀手锏。和一些下拉框式的统计软件不同，R的绘图需要自己动手。

网络上关于R的绘图的文章已有成千上万，在此将自己日常工作要用到的一些绘图功能做一记录。

首先是最简单的在quartz或者X11下作图。

x <- c(1:10, 10:1)
plot(x, type = "p")

将图保存到pdf文件中。（保存为jpeg、png等格式的方法类似）

pdf("pdf_filename.pdf")
x <- c(1:10, 10:1)
plot(x, type = "n")
lines(1:length(x), x)
dev.off()

使用渐变色作图

svg("output.svg", width=10)
#png("1.png")
df = read.table("system_monitor.log")
loadavg = df$V2
timeFormat = "%Y-%m-%D-%H:%M:%S"
times = as.POSIXct(strptime(df$V1, timeFormat))
n = length(loadavg)
idx = as.integer(1:100 * (n * 0.01))
y = c(min(loadavg), loadavg, min(loadavg))
x = c(1,1:n,n)
plot(x, y, type="n", xlab="Seconds", ylab="load average", panel.first=grid(), xaxt = "n")
for (i in seq(255, 0, -3)) {
    #yy = c(0, ((loadavg - min(loadavg)) * (1 - i / 255)), 0)
    yy = y - (y - min(loadavg)) * (1 - i / 255)
    polygon(x, yy, col=rgb(1, i/255, 0), border=NA)
}
axis(1, at=x, labels=df$V1[x])
dev.off()
